titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Friday

lg.l: Confounded be all Zion’s foes
O let them perish at the root
As grass upon the housetop grows
And withers ere its blossoms shoot
It mocks the mower with decay
It puts the reapers hand to shame
Nor passer by shall stop to say,
We bless you in Jehovah’s name

div.p: Psalm 130—

lg.l: Out of the depths I cry to thee
My voice O Lord Jehovah hear
O let thine eyes my Sorrows see
Lend to my suppliant prayer thine ear
Shouldst thou to treasure sins incline
O, who, before thee, Lord could stand
But mercy, gracious God is thine
That all may fear thy chastening hand.

div.p: Met Dr Condict in the Committee room of Manufactures— Ask’d Mr Clark for two Clerks to assert the Manufacture Documents.

H.R.U.S.— Sundry Affairs till 1. P.M— Bouldin finished his Speech. Pendleton succeeded— Vote to strike out first Section of M’Duffie’s Bill, after no Quorum and a Call of the House— My Bill then taken up. Read by Sections—Jenifer moves to strike out the first Section of my Bill—offers no substitute. Committee rise and ask leave to sit again— Adjourn—
H. G. Spafford—
2. IV:15. Saturday

lg.l: My Soul doth in Jehovah trust
The Lord is my Salvation’s home
I wait the coming of the just
More than the watchman for the morn
O Israël, in the Lord confide
To thee his bounties are extreme
With thee his mercy shall abide—
And all thy trespasses redeem

div.p: Psalm 131.

lg.l: Not proud, not haughty is my heart
Nor vainly would aspire
Mine eyes no scornful glance impart
Nor lofty things desire
My thoughts, my actions, meek and mild
Jehovah shall reward
My Soul is as a weaned child
O Israel—trust the Lord—

div.p: Called at Ward and Noyes’s met Dr Condict in Committee-room. Assorting Letters and Papers. H.R.U.S.— Bills upon the Territories— J. L. Kerr and J. W. Taylor in the Chair successively. Territory of Huron or of Ouisconsin. Root’s speeches against it. Wing in its favour— Ashley spoke to me about lead— Henry King about Spirits. Letcher about Cotton bagging— House adjourned at 4— C. J. Ingersoll, here this Evening— Letter from L. C. Adams at Quincy— Unable to write this Evening. Saw Macauleys Brussels carpeting. Cowperthwait
3. V.15 Sunday— Psalm 132.

lg.l: Remember David, and his woes—
O Lord, and how to thee he swore
The mighty God of Jacob knows
How he pour’d forth his votive prayer
No—to my house I will not go
Nor on my weary Couch lie down
Mine eyes no wink of Sleep shall know
Nor Slumber shall mine eye lids crown.
Till for the Lord I find a place
No more in wandering Tents to rove,
The mighty God of Jacob’s race
We found it in Ephrath’s grove—
Come to his Temple let us go
Before his footstool let us fall
Be this thy resting place below
Have with thy Ark—O Lord of all.

div.p: Heard Mr Smith. Mark 12.27. He is the God not of the dead but of the living.— Rain— In the afternoon—few hearers Mr Smith, expounded the hymns, which he gave out to be sung and prayed twice, but gave no Sermon. I called twice on Mr M’Lane, Secretary of the Treasury. In the Evening went with him to his Office. Spirits imported and lead are articles omitted from his Bill by mistake. They are in the Act of 1828. He still thinks my Bill, too favourable to the manufacturing Interest, and that one less favourable will pass—
4. V. Monday.

lg.l: O Lord, thy Priesthood righteous make,
And let thy Saints their joy display
Nor for thy Servant David’s sake
Turn thine anointed’s face away—
The Lord in Truth to David swore
And made his stedfast purpose known
Thy Sons the Diadem shall wear
Thy Children sit upon the throne
And if my Statutes they obey—
And Israel’s God alone adore
Their children shall the Sceptre sway
Unmov’d, till time shall be no more
For Zion, hath Jehovah blest—
There is the dwelling of his choice
This is my everlasting rest—
Here to abide will I rejoice.

div.p: H.R.U.S. met at 10 O’Clock. Petitions received, and Resolutions offered. Second Harbour Bill—debated with much chicanery— Yeas and Nays many times taken— Clayton calls for them upon a mere amendment of form— Majorities increase against him— He withdraws—after calls— Tariff Bill postponed— Virginia claim bill— Adjourned at 4. Dined with Carson. Company of about 30. Calhoun, Clay, Webster, Poindexter, Bibb, Hayne, Wickliffe, Daniel, W. R. Davis, N. Biddle and others. A strange assortment— I stop’d with N. Biddle at his lodgings at Gadsby’s. Wrote to H. Ewart. Philadelphia—and he to Mr. M’Ilvaine to take his bill for £25 after making enquiries
5. V:15. Tuesday.

lg.l: Abundance o’er her I will shed
And with Salvation clothe her Priests.
Will satisfy her poor with bread,
And shouts of joy shall crown her feasts
My hand shall burnish David’s fame
My lamp enlighten all his vows.
And while his foes are clothed with shame
The crown shall glitter on his brows.

div.p: Psalm 133.

lg.l: How good—how pleasant is the sight—
Fraternal Unions blest abode
Tis like that Ointment’s pure delight
Down Aaron’s beard and garb that flowd.
Til like the dew on Hermon’s side
Or Zion’s summit that descends
And there forever shall abide
The bliss, the Lord Jehovah sends.

div.p: Mr Reynold’s here— Going for Boston this Morning— H.R.U.S. Bills at 3d. reading postponed. Harbour-Bill with the rest 86. 83 Tariff Bill— Stewart’s amendment and Speech. Jenifer’s Amendment and Speech— Committee rose. Carr moves reconsideration of Harbour bill postponement—carried Bill passed 101–75. Wickliffe’s notice of Bank Report document—discussion—irritation Adjourned at 6. T. R. Mitchell and Richardson of S.C. here— Abbot Lawrence and Jonas B. Brown here. Conversation upon the Tariff.
6. IV:45. Wednesday. Psalm 134.

lg.l: Bless him ye Servants of the Lord
His praise in nightly hymns record
Lift up your hearts with glee
Bless him who made the Earth and skies
And O, from Zion’s mount may rise
His blessings upon thee.

div.p: Psalm 135.

lg.l: Praise ye the Lord— Praise ye his name
Praise him ye Servants of the Lord
Sound in his holy house his fame
His praise within his Courts record
To praise Jehovah’s name—how sweet
Jacob finds favour in his sight
His praise—how pleasant to repeat
For Israel is the Lord’s delight
I know the Lord—that he is great
Above all Gods exalted high
His word is Law, his will is fate
On Earth, in Ocean—in the sky
His vapours from the Earth ascend
In vain his flashing thunders float
His treasures mighty whirlwinds send
And Egypt’s all first born he smote

div.p: Committee on Manufactures at 9. Horn and Worthington only present. Dr Condict afterwards. Bill from the Senate for admission of Rail-road Iron free referred to the Committee reported to H.R.U.S. without amendment.

Tariff Bill in Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Speight Chairman— I explained the difference between our Tariff-Bill and Stewart’s Amendment alias the Senate Bill— Jenifer’s Amendments rejected— Hoffman offers an Amendment to the Bill. Question of Order— Appeal from Chairman’s decision 69. 69. tie. Chairman decides. Hoffman withdraws his Amendment. Davis commences his Speech— Genl. S. Van Rensselaer and two daughters here— Burd of Pennsylvania, and Orbison with Letter from C. Shaler and
7. V. Thursday.

lg.l: O Egypt, how did he appal
Thy Pharaoh, in the midst of thee
Before him how the Nations fall
What kings are slain by his decree
Sihon of Amorites the Lord
And Og, and all Canaan’s might
He gave their Lands to Israel’s sword
He made them all, his People’s right.
Thy name forever shall endure
Thy Memory through all ages last
The Lord his People shall secure
In future time as in the past
The Lord his Servants shall behold
To them his bounty still expands
But heathen idols—Silver—Gold
These are the work of human hands

div.p: H.R.U.S— Statements of the Speaker respecting payment of members in anticipation of the appropriation— New debate Letcher moves the Speaker’s Statement, be appended to the Report— Felder retracts. Patton pouts upon the passage of the Report alluding to this document. Evans of Maine reads the passage of the Constitution about appropriations. Arnold sarcastic—Cambreleng hypocritical—Wickliffe indignant. Previous question. Tariff—Davis finished his Speech, and mov’d amendments—T R. Mitchell—adjourned at 4. Letter to my Son Charles.
8. V. Friday.

lg.l: No utterance, from their mouths proceeds
Eyes they possess but cannot see
No sound to reach their ears succeeds
Nor in their nostrils breath can be
And like themselves their makers are
And all who faith in them profess
O house of Israel, kneel in prayer
The Lord, O house of Israel bless
The Lord, O house of Levi praise
O, ye that fear him, bless his name
Ye Saints, your tuneful voices raise
From Zion’s mount his praise proclaim
Jerusalem, exalt thy voice
He dwells in thee—his praise record
Ye tribes of Israel, all rejoice.
Praise, chosen People, praise the Lord

div.p: H.R.U.S.— Met at ten— No Call of the House— Bill for carrying into effect the Treaty with France, went through Committee of the whole. Wickliffe in the Chair—reported to the house, and passed to be engrossed— Drayton moves to suspend the rule for private bills to take up the Tariff bill. Carried— I moved a call of the House, which the Speaker refused to put— Committee of the whole on the Tariff-bill— Bell of Tennessee, made half a Speech of three hours— Then offered to finish or asked the Committee to rise— Evans of Maine took the floor; but the Committee rose— House soon after adjourned. I presented papers from the Treasury Department to be printed
10 June. Note at 90 days to Georgetown Union Bank 5000 dollars
9. V. Saturday Psalm 136.

lg.l: Thanks, thanks, to Jehovah, the Lord let us give
For his Mercy endureth forever
Loud thanks to the God of all Gods, while we live
For his Mercy endureth forever
O, with thanks to the Lord of all Lords let us run
For his Mercy endureth forever
To him who alone, mighty wonders hath done
For his Mercy endureth forever.
To him who by Wisdom the Heavens hath made
For his Mercy endureth forever
To him who the Earth oer the waters display’d
For his Mercy endureth forever.
To him whose great lights oer the firmament sway,
For his Mercy endureth forever
The Sun to rule over Creation by day
For his Mercy endureth forever.

div.p: J. S. Roberts from Philadelphia. with a Letter from J. Sergeant about chemicals.
H.R.U.S— Bill for Mounted volunteers, against Indians in Illinois passed through Committee of the whole. and passed.
Tariff-Bill—Bell of Tennessee finished his Speech in three hours U. F. Doubleday read a short Speech, and offered an Amendment— Evans of Maine took the floor— Adjourned
Letter from W M’Ilvaine to N. Biddle imposture of pretended H. Ewart detected— Received many Letters.
10. V. Sunday.

lg.l: The Moon and the Stars to illumine the Night
For his Mercy endureth forever—
To him, who the first born of Egypt did smite
For his Mercy endureth forever
With Israël brought out from the midst of their Land
For his Mercy endureth forever
With an outstretched arm, and omnipotent hand
For his Mercy endureth forever.
Him who of the red sea divided the mass
For his Mercy endureth forever
And made through the midst of it Israel to pass
For his Mercy endureth forever.
Who Pharaoh’s host in the Sea overthrew
For his Mercy endureth forever
And led his own People the Wilderness through,
For his Mercy endureth forever.

div.p: Heard Mr Smith, from 2. Thessalonians 3.1.
Lynch Dominick, and Irving Washington.
Ecclesiastes 3.9.

N. Biddle here this Evening. Expects the Bank Bill to pass the Senate to-morrow. Going to Philadelphia Thunder Shower Biddle spoke of Ingham’s publication in the Philadelphia Sentinel— J. Branch read me yesterday a Letter from judge Daniel, a friend of his in North-Carolina making mention of me, and lamenting the prospects of nullification and disunion—
11. V. Monday.

lg.l: Who smote famous kings, in their fearful array
For his Mercy endureth forever
And with hand unresisted great Monarchs did slay
For his Mercy endureth forever
Sihon king of the Amorites fought but in vain
For his Mercy endureth forever
And Og king of Bashan at Edrei was slain
For his Mercy endureth forever.
To him who their Land, on our fathers bestow’d
For his Mercy endureth forever
And gave it for Israel his Servant’s abode
For his Mercy endureth forever.
To him who remember’d our wants and our woes
For his Mercy endureth forever
To him who redeem’d us from armies of foes
For his Mercy endureth forever.
Who food to all flesh in his goodness imparts
For his Mercy endureth forever.
O give thanks to the God of all worlds in your hearts
For his Mercy endureth forever.

div.p: Called on the Secretary of the Treasury—L. M’Lane. Kavanagh’s question about drawbacks to Registered Vessels—answered. M’Lane clings to his bill. H.R.U.S— Presented Petition of Mrs Royall and of the Brush-makers—referred—the last printed— Bank Bill came from the Senate. Tariff. Evans of Maine occupied the day, by one Speech— Clay of Alabama, Clayton, Burges, up. Committee rose without a Quorum J. S. Roberts and Mott of Philadelphia here this Evening— Summer sets in— Wrote to L.C.A.
12. V. Tuesday. Psalm 137

lg.l: Where Babylon’s proud turrets rise
Seated the rivers banks along
We mourn’d beneath our tyrants eyes
Who taunting, ask’d of us a song
To notes of woe, our Souls were strung
Captives—our vigils sad we kept
Our harps upon the willows hung
Remember’d Zion’s Mount, and wept.
How shall we answer to the call—
The How tune in strange Lands the anthem to set
O let my right hand lifeless fall
If I Jerusalem forget
If to remember thee I cease
Or hold thee not my chief delight
O banish from my bosom Peace
My tongue with speechless palsy smite

div.p: H.R.U.S. Summer heat— Boon’s Resolution for adjournment. goes over a day— Slade offers a Resolution for J. Randolph’s accounts— Bank Bill from Senate read first and second time— Thompson of Ohio moves to postpone to first Monday in December. call of the House—postponement rejected 111. 88—goes over— Tariff-Bill— Clay of Alabama—Speech of three hours— Choate and Root claim the floor— Speight decides for Choate— Root appeals Choate yields the floor Root wishes the pound Sterling to be fixed at 4.86— Attempts to adjourn fail. Wilde takes the floor and speaks till 7— Adjourn— Mr Deming Jarves andhere this Evening. Mrs Tudor sent for me and countermanded the order.
13. IV:30. Wednesday.

lg.l: Jerusalem—how hard thy fate
O Lord, by Edom’s sons defied
Pursued with unrelenting hate
Raze, raze her to the ground, they cried
Daughter of Babylon, O shake
Ere on thy neck the avenger treads
Blest he, thy infants who shall take,
And dash against the Stones their heads.

div.p: Psalm 138.

lg.l: Thee, with my whole heart, will I praise
Before the Gods, my God and king
Within thy house, my voice will raise
And of thy Truth and goodness sing
Thou, Lord didst magnify thy name,
And answer gracious when I cried
Thee shall the kings of Earth proclaim
By thee is strength of Soul supplied

div.p: Mr Abbot Lawrence and twelve other agents for the manufacturers here. Mrs Tudor sent for me— Postpones her claim till the next Session— H.R.U.S. Bank Bill made the order of the day for next Monday. Boon’s and Slade’s Resolutions laid on the Table— Tariff-Bill Wilde finishes his Speech in three hours— Choate makes an excellent speech of one hour. Burges asks Committee to rise—refused. Speaks an hour and asks them again to rise—refused again— Burd takes the floor— At 6. I left the house with M’Duffie—dined with E. Everett. W. Irving—Livingston and 14. Went in the Evening with M’Duffie to Mrs White’s of Florida Large party— Home at 11. P.M. Showery day
14. V:30. Thursday.

lg.l: Yea, they shall sing Jehovah’s ways
For he, exalted in the skies,
Respect unto the lowly pays
And far, far off the proud descries
In midst of trouble though I go
Thy hand the wrath of man shall break.
Thou shalt not yield me to the foe,
Nor thy own handy-work forsake

div.p: Psalm 139.

lg.l: Lord thou hast search’d my inmost Soul
My distant thoughts to thee are known
And subject all to thy controul
My ways are trac’d by thee alone
My sitting down, my rising up
My thought unutter’d thou dost see.
My path, my pillow and my cup,
All, all, great God, are known to thee

div.p: H.R.U.S— Call of the House. Belated for Committee on the blue book. Bill upon Public Lands postponed— Bill on Virginia Claim opposed by Rest— Tariff Bill at Noon— Clayton’s four hours Speech— In the Library Houston there—“Art.” J. B Sutherland followed Clayton. Left the House at 6. Company to dine. J. C. Calhoun—H. A. S. Dearborn. E. Everett. T. L. M’Kenney—G. M’Duffie C F. Mercer—N. Silsbee G. C. Verplanck—J. G. Watmough. D. Webster and Jos. M. White. Calhoun came late— White’s Turtle and Fox-grape wine. But where is the precious June?
15. V:15. Friday

lg.l: Before, behind me, all around
On me thy heavy hand is lain
But still beyond my reach is found.
Tis higher than I can attain.
How from thy Spirit shall I go?
Or whither, from thy presence flee—
In Heaven above, in Hell below
Vain, vain the thought, to fly from thee
On Morning’s wings should I ascend
And traverse Oceans farthest tide
There led by thee, my way should wend,
There should thy right hand, prove my guide.
In darkness, should I still be seen
Thy light around me still would shine
No darkness from thy sight can screen
Midnight and noon, alike are thine

div.p: Mr Lawrence,and twelve other Gentlemen agents from the manufacturers were here— Then Deming Jarves and a Mr Gilliland. Glass-makers were here. H.R.U.S. The Virginia claim bill; opposed by Mr Root till Noon. Tariff-Bill. Sutherland finished his Speech— D. H. Lewis of Alabama—a furious Speech. Young of Connecticut—modest Jewett of New-York moves to strike out the proviso from Davis’s Amendment. Questions of order. I called for Clayton’s Amendment, but it was refused— Bullard’s Tariff Speech— Carson’s Answer. Wickliffe—Burges— Committee rise at 7. Garsed here this Evening.
16. V. Saturday.

lg.l: For thou, O God, didst form my frame,
And I am wonderfully made
Ere from my Mother’s womb I came
In me thy wonders were display’d
Thou, on my substance, Lord didst look
Wrought in the lowest parts of Earth
My days, recorded in thy book
Were fix’d by thee, before my birth.
Thy thoughts— O God whom I adore—
My wakeful eyes in vain would count
They mock the sands upon the shore
So vast, so boundless their amount.
The wicked, thou, O God, wilt slay
From me, ye bloody men depart—
Thy foes, their blasphemies display
O God, they curse thee at the heart.

div.p: H.R.U.S— Resolution for purchasing the 4th. and 5th. Volumes of Gales and Seaton’s debates Reported from the Library Committee and finally passed. Tariff Bill. T. Burges spoke five hours— Spanning between R. H. Wilde and him— Calls for the question. Jewett’s motion rejected— P. Thomas Carson. Davis renews his amendment—discussed motions for committee to rise rejected. at last. at 9 P.M. a motion prevails 76 to 75— Horn presented this Morning a Memorial from R. M. Whitney— Laid on the Table Motion to print it also laid upon the Table.
17. V. Sunday

lg.l: Lord—hate I not, all thee that hate
My inmost thoughts to thee are known
Preserve me from their hepless fate
I count thy enemies my own
Search me, O God! my bosom try
Prove me—my inmost Soul survey
Teach me, the wicked to defy
And lead me—lead me in thy way.

div.p: Psalm 140.

lg.l: O—save me from the Sons of strife—
The man of blood whom I abhor
Whose mischief plot aga broaching mischief seeks my life
And daily stirs against me War.
Their Tongues are like the Serpent’s fang
From them the adders poison flows
O God—defend me from the gang.
Save, save me from my ruthless foes.

div.p: Bath in the Potowmack, with John. Great change on the strand of the river— All the trees are gone— My old rocks yet remain— Heard a young Stranger preach for Mr Smith from Matthew 25.14–30. The parable of the Talents— Visits from J. S. Barrell and F. Hassler, who talked much of the Tariff, and of weights and measures. Fahrenheit 94. Very severe Thunder shower— Wrote during as much of the day as I could. Omitted to attend the afternoon Service, overcome by heat and lassitude.
18. V. Monday

lg.l: The proud for me have laid a snare
And oer my path a net have spread
O, Lord Jehovah—hear my prayer
Thou art my Saviour God, I said
Jehovah—my Salvation’s strength
In Battle’s day, my shield of brass
O, let the Scorner not at length
His base devices bring to pass
Let him not prosper in his pride
And they who compass me around
Let their own lips their mischief chide
Let their own words, their deeds confound
Shower on their heads the burning coal
And let them in the fire be cast—
In deepest waters let them roll
Nor from them ever rise at last.

div.p: H.R.U.S— Bill for increasing Medical department of the army expenditures— The Virginia claim Bill. Root’s continued speech against it— Suspended at Noon— Tariff-Bill— Davis’s Amendment modified— Drayton and Hoffman against it—and Polk—rejected— Amendments in detail— Many on the Articles of Wool and Woollens— Turbulent, and tumultuous Scene— Adjourned between 8 and 9 in the Evening— Charles C. Johnston a member of the House from Virginia was drown’d last Night at Alexandria— J. Bailey here this Evening. Heavy thunder shower again this Morning.
19. IV:30. Tuesday.

lg.l: O, let no man of evil tongue
Succeed and prosper here below
Let Slander, by herself be stung
And hunted to her overthrow.
Of thee, the afflicted, in distress
Of thee, the Poor, reliev’d, shall tell.
Thy name, the righteous, Lord, shall bless—
The good, shall in thy presence dwell.

div.p: Psalm 141.

lg.l: O Lord Jehovah, haste to me
And listen, when to thee I cry
As evening sacrifice to thee
O let me life my hands on high
Put thou, before my mouth a guard
And of my lips, keep thou the door
The wicked far from me discard
Nor let me banquet on their store

div.p: Cool after the Showers— H.R.U.S. Mr. May of Boston—respecting tinned wire—

Judge Bouldin, of Virginia announced the death of C. C. Johnston, and pronounced his Eulogy— Left two children. Moves the Resolutions—to attend the funeral, and wear crape— For a Committee of Arrangements for the funeral, which was immediately appointed by the Speaker and announced.— Message to the Senate— House adjourned. Wrote Letter for H. W. Conner to La Fayette— Sent to Carson— Walked home. Did not attend the funeral— Writing and reading all day— Visit to the Garden— Strawberries gone. Dr Wallace here— Takes Slaver of Mad dogs. Bit by Mocassin Snake.
20. V. Wednesday.

lg.l: Lord—let the righteous smite my head
His stern rebuke shall be my crown
Its Oil, oer all my sins shall spread
But let not Slander break me down
Their judges stumble o’er the stones
They hear my words—for they are good—
See, scatter’d at the grave, our bones—
Like clods of Earth, and chips of wood.
O Lord my God, be thou mine aid
O leave not destitute my Soul—
Save me from Snares, the vile have laid
Their wicked purposes controul
Their foul devices O confound
In their own Springs let them fall—
While I, with thy protection crown’d
Beneath thy Shield escape them all.

div.p: W. Radcliff, here. Left a pamphlet Memorial— Claim of Robert L. Livingston Exor of Walter Livingston, requesting me to examine it during the recess— Spoke of his own return and removal as Consul at Lima— And of the propos’d Railway over the Isthmus of Panama. H.R.U.S. Bill to increase the Surgeons in the Army. Virginia Claim-Bill— Root finished his Speech against it— Tariff Bill in Committee of the whole—debated Paragraphs of the second Section 18— Once no Quorum— All the decisions against the Manufacturers— L. M’Lane gave me his report prepared to transmit that of Hassler to the Senate; adjourned at 8 P.M. Note to Union Bank, Georgetown. 90 days 3000 dollars.
21. IV.15. Thursday. Psalm 142

lg.l: Unto the Lord my God, I cry
To him my voice ascends in prayer
I pour my plaint to him on high
Before him, my distress declare.
My Spirit was oerwhelm’d with woe
A Snare they spread across my way.
I look’d around me— None would know
I found no refuse—found no Stay
To thee I cry—O God, and say
Thou art my portion in the Land—
I faint— O hear me when I pray
Save me from Persecution’s hand
My Soul from bondage O redeem
And all thy Saints shall gather round
Thy glorious name shall be my theme—
For thou, in Mercy shalt be found.

div.p: H.R.U.S— Virginia Claim Bill Mason replies to Root— Tariff-Bill in Committee of the whole— Reported the Bill with many Amendments. Several times no Quorum. Amendments offered by J. Davis—Jenifer Stewart, Clayton, and Hawkins of N.C. all rejected— M’Duffie’s, and Barringer’s threatening Speeches Davis’s reply— Bouldin’s furious gestures— Rap on my own knuckles. Root moved the Pound Sterling should be valued at 4.86. rejected House adjourned about 7. P.M. John and Mary Evening at Mr Frye’s— Mrs Tudor and her Grandson Charles Stuart here. Disabled myself from writing by contusion— A warning.
22. V. Friday. Psalm 143.

lg.l: O Lord Jehovah, hear my prayer
And let thy Mercy, judgment give
For lest thy tender Mercy spare
Before thee none can stand and live
Mark’d as a victim by my foe
Darkness and Death avenge my Sin
My Soul is overwhelm’d with woe
My heart is desolate within.
I call to Memory days of old
Muse on the wonders of thy hand
In prayer to thee my hands uphold
Thirsting as thirsts a parched land
O Lord Jehovah, lend thine ear
I sink—turn not thy face from me—
Thy loving kindness let me hear.
Guide me—I lift my Soul to thee.

div.p: Brown—Jonas B—Garsed—and J. Connell here— H.R.U.S. Virginia Claim Bill. Previous Question—passed— Tariff Bill. I offered an Amendment in two Sections for valuation by the importer— Not in order— Amendments adopted in Committee of the whole, successively considered— Most of them adopted— That for reducing the duty on Salt disagreed to— That for equalising the duties on French and India Silks agreed to. Crude Salt debate— M’Duffie moves an Amendment for reducing the duties on Cotton manufactures— Adjourned at 6. Mrs Stewart and her Son were here and afterwards Andrew Armstrong and Midshipman Gay son of Payton Gay.
23. IV:30. Saturday.

lg.l: O Lord—redeem me from my foes
The blessings of thy Love display
To thee, my Sorrows I disclose
Let thy good Spirit point my way
Revive me, for thy glory’s sake,
And bring me out of my distress.
The rod of my oppressors break,
O, save thy Servant, Lord and bless.

div.p: Psalm 144.

lg.l: O Lord, my fortress and my Tower—
Thou who hast taught my hands to fight
Who bendest Nations to my power
My Shield, my refuge, my delight
Lord what is man and what his race
That thou shouldst make account of grass
His days a vain and empty space—
Just as successive Shadows pass.

div.p: H.R.U.S.— Joint Resolution from Library Committee to purchase 1250 Copies Documents of Revolutionary War. rejection reconsidered and again rejected 88 to 93. Tariff-Bill. M’Duffie proposes an Amendment in the Cotton Section—rejected. Then one on rolled and hammered Iron—rejected. Jarvis obtains reconsideration of the Crude Salt Section. Again rejected. My Amendment upon the mode of valuation ordered to be printed— J Davis’s Amendment offered and after some discussion— House adjourned at 6. P.M. unable to write with my broken Hand— Huskisson’s Speeches.
24. V. Sunday

lg.l: Bow, mighty God thy Heavens—come down.
The Mountains touch, and they shall smoke
Shoot the sharp arrows of thy frown
Hurl the dread lightning’s deathful stroke
Send from above thy saving hand
On thy redemption I rely.
From Strangers of a distant Land,
Who pledge their right hands to a lie
My voice new strains of rapture sings—
Trills to thy praise, the trembling chord
Tis he gives victory to kings—
He rescues David from the sword
O—save me from the Stranger’s hand
Who pledge their right hand to a lie
So shall our Sons like plants expand
With polish’d gems pillar’d domes, our daughters vie

div.p: Bath in Potomack John was there, but did not go in being very unwell. Dr Huntt here— At Church. Heard Mr Smith Matthew 25.45— W. S. Smith here. Left a return card at Duff Green’s— Visit to G. M’Duffie, and to J. C. Calhoun— Long Conversation with Calhoun upon Constitutional questions and nullification— W. C. Greenleaf made out a list of Anti-Tariff Memorials and Petitions and extracts from Mr Huskisson’s Speeches— Letter and book from W. L. Stone.
25. V. Monday

lg.l: So shall our garners burst with grain
Our Sheep, by thousands and ten thousands breed.
Our oxen, labour’s load sustain
And verdure crown the blooming mead.
Our Streets shall eccho no distress
Nor dread the Terrors of thy rod
Thrice blest the People who confess
The Lord Jehovah, for their God.
Psalm 145. Tehillah
My God—my king—thy name shall be
My everlasting theme of praise
From day to day—will I to thee
The song of grateful rapture raise.
Jehovah’s name all names exceeds
His greatness is beyond compare
Age shall to Age repeat his deeds
Eternity his works declare.

div.p: H.R.U.S. Debate on Resolution for adjournment. Threats of dissolution of the Union— My reply— Called to order by the Speaker— House pass to the orders of the day— I walked home for my Tariff-Bills, which I had inadvertently left on my table— Took them to the Capitol. J. Davis made the Speech in support of his amendment during my absence—Cambreleng, Everett— I offered my amendment upon the valuation—rejected 68 to 112— Davis’s Amendment rejected—about the same. I moved to amend the woollens at 5 per Cent ad valorum, from 40 to 33—rejected— From 40 to 35—carried. Alexander moved to strike out the Section allowing drawback to shipping. House adjourned.
26. V. Tuesday.

lg.l: Yes, of thy glories I will speak
And of thy wondrous works will tell.
Thy terrors make the mighty weak—
Thy mercies grateful hearts shall swell.
Thy goodness, Memory shall record
And all thy righteousness relate
How kind—how gracious is the Lord
To Anger slow—of Mercy great.
The Lord, is bountiful to all
Thy mercies over all extend
Thy Saints, O God, on thee shall call
Thy works shall praise thee without end.
Shall spread the glories of thy sway
Talk of the Splendors of thy throne
Thy kingdom’s Majesty display
And make thy matchless wonders known—

div.p: H.R.U.S— Dunn—Sergeant at arms. Letter of Resignation— Vote not to elect a Sergeant at arms till next Session. Dunn absconded with five or six thousand dollars money of the members of the House.— Tariff Bill— Motion to strike out 10th Section. Campbell P. White’s Amendment— Votes and reconsiderations, Yeas and Nays 7 or 8 Times— Section at last retained 97 to 93— W. Thompson’s and Carson’s Amendments—rejected. I offered an Amendment to the Woollens Article; and the House adjourned. Macauley here this Morning, the Carpet Manufacturer, and Mrs Stewart and her Son Charles this Evening.
27. V. Wednesday.

lg.l: Thy kingdom shall forever stand
Thy power eternity shall crown
Shall prop the falling with thy hand
And raise from Earth the bowed down
The eyes of all upon thee wait
Their meat thou givest them in turn
Thy care is watchful of their fate—
Thine eyes, unerring to discern—
Thy liberal bounty still supplies
Of every living thing the want—
Nor can in mortal bosom rise
Desire, but thou dost freely grant.
The Lord, in all his ways is just
And merciful in all his deeds
Still nigh to them in him who trust
And Truth from him alone proceeds.

div.p: Macauley here this Morning. H.R.U.S.— Boon’s Resolution for adjournment 5. July, rejected 90–96.— Steam-Battery Bill—and St. Francis company Bill, rejected— Tariff-Bill. I moved and lost one amendment upon carpetings. Cambreleng’s motion for reconsideration second— Carried. Speaker’s decision—appeal sustain’d 10th. Section Struck out. Recess from 3 to 4. I dined with J. W. Taylor. Evening Session. Amendments. Previous Question— Bill passed to be engrossed 121. to 65. Adjourned at 10. P.M. I took Edward Everett home
[symbols]
28. V. Thursday

lg.l: The Lord, to all shall lend an ear
Who fear him, and shall crown their joy—
All them that love him he shall hear
And all the wicked shall destroy.
My voice, his glories to proclaim
The song of boundless joy shall raise—
And all mankind shall bless his name
And endless Time shall speak his praise.

div.p: Psalm 146.

lg.l: Praise ye the Lord!— O praise the Lord
Yes! I will praise him while I live—
My Soul, his glories to record—
While I have being, praise shall give
O let not Princes be your trust
Nor take a child of Man for Stay.
Their breath goes forth—they turn to dust
Perish their thoughts that very day.

div.p: Visit to the Count de Survilliers, at Gadsby’s. He is going to Europe Told me his views—and much of his circumstances—declined invitation to dine. H.R.U.S. Resolution passed to adjourn 9. July— Also to pay from the contingencies the members whose monies Dunn had eloped with—

Tariff-Bill— M’Duffie’s Speech of three hours against it. Previous question moved by Heister call of the House. Bill passed 65 to 132. I moved to Amend the Title W. R. Davis, moved a further amendment— E. Everett the previous question which was carried. I told Everett I did not thank him for that. The House soon after adjourned— General Macomb and John Mason here this Evening—
29. V. Friday.

lg.l: How blest is he, who leans for aid
And hope, upon the Lord his God
Who Heaven and Earth and Sea has made,
And rules Creation by his nod
His truth forever shall endure
Th’ oppress’d in him their Saviour see
He feeds the hungry and the poor
He sets the captive bondsman free
The Lord gives vision to the blind;
And raises up the poor oppress’d
The Lord is to the righteous kind
And gives the houseless Stranger rest.
Widow and fatherless relieves
Arrests the wicked in their ways
And still as Zion’s God receives
To everlasting ages, praise.

div.p: Call on D. Webster, with papers relating to the Tariff-Bill— Long conversation with him— Found the House had adjourned, on account of the death of G. E. Mitchell, member from Maryland— Yesterday— Returned home— At the Capitol again at 5. P.M.— Funeral Service by Mr Post and another clergyman.— J. W. Taylor rode with me to the grave-yard— Left him at his lodgings when we came back— Dined with N. Biddle at Gadsby’s—H. Clay, M’Duffie, Daniel, Crawford, Banks, Bullard. Watmough &c were of the Company— Jovial— I came home about 10. P.M.— Wrote this day to L. C. Adams— I am under an agitation of mind, which I sometimes fear may unseat my reason— Nullum Numen adest ni sit Prudentia—
30. V. Saturday. Psalm 147.

lg.l: Praise ye the Lord—’tis good and fair
The Praises of our God to sing—
He makes Jerusalem his care
And Israel’s outcasts home shall bring.
He bids the broken heart be whole
Tis he the wounded bosom heals,
He tells the Stars that oer us roll,
And all their countless names reveals.
Great is our Lord—his power is great
His understanding knows no bound
He raises men of low Estate—
He casts the wicked to the ground.
Sing to the Harp Thanksgiving’s strain
Chant the loud praises of our God—
Who swells the teaming clouds with rain
Who Clothes with grass the Mountain sod.

div.p: Payton Gay called this Morning with a Letter from G. W. La Fayette, to my late brother, to which he asked me, and I promised to reply. H.R.U.S— Sundry Bills. Resolution from Senate for a joint Committee to request P.U.S to appoint a fast day, debated. I moved an Amendment—lost. Resolution carried by yeas and nays—Bank Bill— Motion to postpone till 1st. Monday in December lost 100 to 75— To go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union also lost. M’Duffie offers an Amendment Beardsley a super-amendment lost—Wayne’s—lost. House adjourned after 5 P.M. My cough has returned— I wrote to W. L. Stone.

For the Mountains shall depart, and the hills be removed, but my kindness shall not depart from thee, neither shall the covenant of my peace be removed, saith the Lord that hath mercy on thee. Isaiah 53.10.
Instead of the thorn shall come up the fir tree; and instead of the brier shall come up the myrtle tree; and it shall be to the Lord, for a name, for an everlasting sign that shall not be cut off.
23 O Lord, I know that the way of man, is not in himself; it is not in man that walketh to direct his steps.
24. O Lord, correct me, but with judgment; not in thine anger, lest thou bring me to nothing. Jeremiah 10.
Weep ye not for the dead, neither bemoan him; but weep sore for him that goeth away; for he shall return no more, nor see his native Country. Jeremiah 22.10.
And Huzzab shall be led away captive, she shall be brought up, and her maids shall lead her as with the voice of doves, tabering upon their breasts Nahum 2.7.
11. For the stone shall cry out of the wall, and the beam out of the timber shall answer it
12. Wo to him that buildeth a town with blood, and stablisheth a city by iniquity. Habakkuk 2.11.12
